awd_titl_txt: Asymptotic vs. Uniform Approximation in Dynamical Systems and Number Theory
awd_abstract_narration:
This project deals with certain algebraic dynamical systems and their applications to number theory. A dynamical system here stands for an abstract set of points together with an evolution law that governs the way points move over time. Such abstract dynamical systems form the basis for models of a wide range of important phenomena in science and engineering. It turns out that also many problems in mathematics concerning simultaneous approximation of real numbers by rational numbers can be understood in terms of the behavior of dynamical systems. Furthermore, systems that arise in this context are of algebraic nature, which makes it possible to use a wide variety of sophisticated tools for their investigation. This research project aims to advance the framework of algebraic dynamical systems in approximation theory, develop new methods, and obtain far-reaching generalizations of results in the field. Graduate and undergraduate students will be involved in the project and introduced to new methods and techniques in number theory and dynamics. These students will also supervise research projects within the framework of the PRIMES program, an after-school research program for high school students. 

During recent years there has been an influx of new ideas concerning connections between Diophantine approximation and dynamical systems. This research project continues the study of phenomena in both homogeneous dynamics and number theory in two directions: related to so-called asymptotic and uniform approximation. Among mathematical tools to be employed are: quantitative non-divergence on the space of lattices, Schmidt games and their modifications, integral inequalities of Eskin-Margulis-Mozes, exponential mixing, equidistribution properties, and geometry of numbers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project dealt with certain algebraic dynamical systems and their applications to number theory. A dynamical system here stands for an abstract set of points together with an evolution law that governs the way points move over time. Such abstract dynamical systems form the basis for models of a wide range of important phenomena in science and engineering. It turns out that also many problems in mathematics concerning simultaneous approximation of real numbers by rational numbers can be understood in terms of the behavior of dynamical systems. Furthermore, systems that arise in this context are of algebraic nature, which makes it possible to use a wide variety of sophisticated tools for their investigation.

The main theme of the project was studying of phenomena in both homogeneous dynamics and number theory in two directions: related to so-called asymptotic and uniform approximation. Here are some examples. Jointly with Mirzadeh, the PI generalizedg a theorem of Kadyrov on the Hausdorff dimension of exceptional sets in homogeneous dynamics, and used it to estimate from above the dimension of sets of weighted uniformly badly approximable systems of linear forms. With Moshchevitin the PI estimated uniform Diophantine exponents of points on algebraic hypersurfaces, and then complemented this result by constructing singular vectors and linear forms on manifolds  with Moshchevitin and Weiss.

A new uniform set-up of the throey of shrinking targets in dynamical systems was developed by the PI with Konstantoulas and Richter by studying the so-called essentially always hitting property and proving several concrete results for the full/zero measure of the corresponding orbits.

With An and Guan the PI proved the winning property of the set of points avoiding a fixed target in the set-up of homogeneous dynamics, with applications to vaues of generalized binary quadratic forms.

Another direction was related to rational points on quadric hypersurfaces, whose distribution was stidued using dynamics. Suppose that there is a dense set of those points. How are they distributed? and how likely is it to find a rational point with relatively small denominator not far from a typical point on the hypersurface? This was the subject of the PI's now published paper with  Fishman, Merrill and Simmons. The dynamical system responsible for the approximation properties happens to be a flow on a quotient of the special orthogonal group of the corresponding quadratic form.

Yet another direction is studying improvement of Dirichlet's theorem, which is related to the behavior of certain trajectories near critical loci in the space of lattices. Extenstions to arbitrary norm appeared in several papers with Rao. There the PI studied Dirichlet-improvable vectors for cylindrical norms and in a weighted set-up. Dynamical Borel-Cantelli lemmas for uniform approximation were established on space of 2-lattices with Yu, and then in much bigger generality with Strombergsson and Yu. The latter work dealt with finding necessary and sufficient conditions for psi-Dirichlet-improvability of generic systems of linear forms. A related work with de Saxce, Shah and Yang estalished criteria for equidistribution of translates of generic points on straight lines in the space of lattices, implying definite results concerning Dirichlet-improvability of generic points on planar lines.

Two papers were written by Skenderi: there the PI proved new Khintchine type theorems for subhomogeneous functions, both in asymptotic and in uniform Diophantine approximation set-up.

A substantial part of the PI's activity was related to the Dimension Drop phenomenon in homogeneous dynamics. With Mirzadeh the PI proved  the Dimension Drop Conjecture for a special flow on the space of lattices, then generalized it to an axiomatic set-up including many special cases, as well as to escape on average on compact homogeneous spaces.

Other results include: computing measure and dimension of sets arising in studying product of weighted continued fraction coefficients (with Bakhtawar, Hussain and Wang), proving a new dynamical Borel-Cantelli lemma for recurrence under Lipschitz twists (with Zheng), and studying ubiquitous systems in the product setting (with Wang).
